Product.title: Product
Product.description: Represents a product that can be scanned and added to the pantry or shopping list.

description.description: A detailed description of the product.

imageUrl.description: URL to an image of the product.

PantryItem.title: PantryItem
PantryItem.description: Represents an item in the user's pantry.

id.description: Unique identifier for the pantry item.

productId.description: Reference to the Product. (Relationship: Product 1:N PantryItem)

quantity.description: Quantity of the product in the pantry.

dateAdded.description: Date when the item was added to the pantry.

ShoppingListItem.title: ShoppingListItem
ShoppingListItem.description: Represents an item on the user's shopping list.

id.description: Unique identifier for the shopping list item.

productId.description: Reference to the Product. (Relationship: Product 1:N ShoppingListItem)

addedDate.description: Date the item was added to the shopping list.

isPurchased.description: Flag indicating if the item has been purchased.

Expense.title: Expense
Expense.description: Represents an expense tracked by the user.

productId.description: Reference to the Product. (Relationship: Product 1:N Expense)

supermarketId.description: Reference to the Supermarket where the expense occurred. (Relationship: Supermarket 1:N Expense)

Supermarket.title: Supermarket
Supermarket.description: Represents a supermarket where the user shops.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to organize product information, user pantries, shopping lists, expenses, and supermarket details. It leverages path-based ownership for user-specific data (pantry items, shopping list items, and expenses) to ensure strong security and simple rules. Products and Supermarkets are stored at the root level, as they are intended to be globally accessible and managed. 

**Authorization Independence:** This design achieves Authorization Independence by using path-based ownership for user-specific data. For example, pantry items are stored under `/users/{userId}/pantry/{pantryItemId}`. This eliminates the need for `get()` calls in security rules to verify ownership.  

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):** The segregation of user-specific data into their respective user subcollections enables secure `list` operations. A user can only list items under their own `userId` which is validated by the `request.auth.uid`. This ensures that users cannot filter or access data belonging to other users. Products and Supermarkets do not contain sensitive information, so QAPs are less relevant here.
